review.title: Improving the Accuracy and Efficiency of MAP Inference for Markov Logic
review.abstract: In this work we present Cutting Plane Inference (CPI), a Maximum A Posteriori (MAP) inference method for Statistical Relational Learning. Framed in terms of Markov Logic and inspired by the Cutting Plane Method, it can be seen as a meta algorithm that instantiates small parts of a large and complex Markov Network and then solves these using a conventional MAP method. We evaluate CPI on two tasks, Semantic Role Labelling and Joint Entity Resolution, while plugging in two different MAP inference methods: the current method of choice for MAP inference in Markov Logic, MaxWalkSAT, and Integer Linear Programming. We observe that when used with CPI both methods are significantly faster than when used alone. In addition, CPI improves the accuracy of MaxWalkSAT and maintains the exactness of Integer Linear Programming.
histories: Appears in Proceedings of the Twenty-Fourth Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence (UAI2008)
review.COMMENTS: Appears in Proceedings of the Twenty-Fourth Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence (UAI2008)

metadata.title: Improving the Accuracy and Efficiency of MAP Inference for Markov Logic

sections.text: In this paper, we present Cutting Plane Inference (CPI), a maximum A posteriori (MAP) inference method for statistical relationship learning. According to Markov logic and inspired by the Cutting Plane Method, it can be considered a meta-algorithm that instantiates small pieces of a large and complex Markov network and then solves them using a conventional MAP method. We evaluate CPI using two tasks, semantic role labeling and joint entity resolution, while incorporating two different MAP inference methods: the current method of choice for MAP inferences in Markov logic, MaxWalkSAT and Integer Linear Programming. We find that both methods are significantly faster when used with CPI. In addition, CPI improves the accuracy of MaxWalkSAT and maintains the accuracy of Integer Linear Programming.

sections.heading: 2 MARKOV LOGIC
sections.text: It can be considered a formalism that extends the logic of the first order to allow formulas that can be violated with a certain uncertainty. Seen from an alternative point of view, it is an expressive template language that uses the formulations of the first order to select a particular verb that acts as an agent for a particular verb. We also maintain a number of additional predicates that provide information about the verb. For example, the left predicate can be the one that points to the left side of the verb. The row of all predicates is called P.

sections.heading: 3.1 MAXWALKSAT
sections.text: Previous work [Richardson and Domingos, 2005] found y е using MaxWalkSAT (MWS), an approximate RandomWalk method that has been used very successfully to solve weighted SAT problems [Kautz et al., 1996]. It begins with the assignment of a random state to all mass atoms and continues with the repeated selection of a random, unsatisfactory mass clause. With the probability q, a random mass atom of this clause is selected and its state reversed. With the probability 1 − q, the mass atom that causes the greatest increase in the total weight s (y, x) when turning over is selected to flip. The process repeats until a fixed number of turns is reached. Optionally, one can try again to find a better y, each time starting with a new random solution. 2In the case where multiple maxima exist, we can select one of them.

sections.heading: 3.2 INTEGER LINEAR PROGRAMMING
sections.text: Integer Linear Programming [ILP, Winston and Venkataramanan, 2003] refers to the process of optimizing a linear objective function taking into account linear inequalities and the limitation that all (or some) variables are integer. ILP has been used in many tasks to solve MAP problems [Roth and Yih, 2005, Clarke and Lapata, 2007] due to its accuracy, its declarative nature, and the availability of highly efficient ILP solutions. Here we present a generic mapping of Ground Markov Networks in Markov Logic to ILPs.3 We begin by replacing each functional application with a binary variable formula.

sections.heading: 4 CUTTING PLANE INFERENCE
sections.text: We will show in the empirical section of this paper that performing inferences using the full grounding of a Markov logic network can be slow and, in the case of MWS, also inaccurate. We will now present an algorithm that attempts to overcome this problem by instantiating only parts of the entire Ground Markov network and applying a standard inference method to this network.

sections.heading: 4.1 ALGORITHM
sections.text: The proposed algorithm is a variant of the "Cutting Plane" approach adopted by "Operations Research" (Dantzig et al., 1954); the proposed algorithm is a variant of the "Cutting Plane" approach adopted by "Operations Research" (Dantzig et al., 1954); the proposed algorithm is a variant of the "Cutting Plane" approach adopted by the "Cutting Plane" solution; the current problem is expanded and solved anew by these new constraints; the process is repeated until no more violated constraints can be found; instead of looking for violated constraints, Cutting Plane Inference (CPI) looks for feature products in Equation 2 that do not contribute to the total. Specifically, for each formula and given (y), we look for all tuples, separated (ell, y, x).

sections.heading: 4.2 SEPARATION
sections.text: An integral part of the CPI is the separation step, in which we have to find all the fundamentals c of a formula φ and the weight w that are not maximally fulfilled (according to Eq.3) for a given solution y. However, in this step the paradigm of Statistical Relational Learning comes into play. In a (meaningful) Markov network we do not have descriptions of higher order of its characteristics. To perform separations then means to evaluate all characteristics of the network. However, in the Markov logic we can do it better. [v / c] is true.

sections.heading: 4.3 RELATED WORK
sections.text: We can either use it to address ILP problems by solving their LP relaxation and, if the solution is fractional, create additional constraints. Alternatively, we could formulate this problem as an instance of theory testing, but all axioms are grounded atoms and we are looking for all the fundamentals the formula applies to - database technology is optimized for this setting. The holistic solution is known to meet. Or we can use it to solve problems with a large number of constraints, such as ILP formulations of the Travelling Salesman Problem [Dantzig et al., 1954], without including them all. Our work follows previous research in the MAP Inference [Riedel and Clarke, 2006, Anguelov et al., 2004, Tromble and Eisner, 2006, Sontag and Jaakkola, 2007], where cutting plans are used to avoid all constraints in advance.

sections.heading: 5 EXPERIMENTS
sections.text: In both cases, we want to investigate how CPI affects the runtime and accuracy of two base solvers: MWS and ILP. For all experiments, we use our own Markov logic implementation, which runs on a Pentium 4 with 2.8 Ghz and 4Gb RAM. All CPI systems use local formulas with only one hidden atom to generate the original grounding G0.

sections.heading: 5.2 JOINT ENTITY RESOLUTION
sections.text: This year, it is more than ever before in the history of the city.

sections.heading: 6 CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this paper, we introduced Cutting Plane Inference (CPI), a novel method for finding MAP solutions in Markov logic that incrementally solves partial versions of the full Ground Markov Network based on a Cutting Plane approach. While Cutting Planes have already been used for specific MAP inference problems, this work shows how they can be generalized and integrated into a framework for statistical relative learning in which they are automatically available for a wide range of tasks. Essentially, our method serves as a meta algorithm that switches between first-order deterministic query processing on the one hand and numerical optimization of sub-problems on the other. We evaluated the proposed algorithm using two real tasks for which we have shown MWS to work poorly: Joint Entity Resolution and Semantic Role Labeling. In both cases, CPI makes an exact method (P) more efficient, while remaining both faster and more accurate than a pre-sewing method.

metadata.abstractText: In this work we present Cutting Plane Inference (CPI), a Maximum A Posteriori (MAP) inference method for Statistical Relational Learning. Framed in terms of Markov Logic and inspired by the Cutting Plane Method, it can be seen as a meta algorithm that instantiates small parts of a large and complex Markov Network and then solves these using a conventional MAP method. We evaluate CPI on two tasks, Semantic Role Labelling and Joint Entity Resolution, while plugging in two different MAP inference methods: the current method of choice for MAP inference in Markov Logic, MaxWalkSAT, and Integer Linear Programming. We observe that when used with CPI both methods are significantly faster than when used alone. In addition, CPI improves the accuracy of MaxWalkSAT and maintains the exactness of Integer Linear Programming.
